[[Multiplayer game|Multiplayer]] |platforms = [[FM Towns]]
[[NEC PC-9801]]
[[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]]
[[Sega Genesis|Genesis]]
[[X68000]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Aerobiz'''''|エアーマネジメント 大空に賭ける||"Air Management: Ōzora ni Kakeru"}} is a [[business simulation game|business simulation]] [[video game]] for the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]] and [[Sega Genesis|Mega Drive/Genesis]] [[game console]]s, released in 1992 by [[Koei]].{{cite web|title=Aerobiz Game Information|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/aerobiz|publisher=MobyGames|accessdate=12 June 2011}} It was also released for the [[FM Towns]], [[PC-9800 Series|PC-9801]] and [[X68000]] computer platforms in Japan. As [[chief executive officer|CEO]] of a budding international [[airline]], the player has a limited amount of time to expand their business to become the industry leader against three other airlines (either [[artificial intelligence|AI]]-controlled or human opponents). The player has an amount of control over how their airline develops, such as the name, investments, what routes to fly, plane purchases, and other various aspects, while at the mercy of world events such as politics (for instance, if the player runs his or her airline out of Moscow, he or she can initially only buy Soviet planes and will have a harder time negotiating with Western nationsHandbook pp.29) and natural disasters. The player can also get the company involved in peripheral businesses such as [[hotel]]s and shuttle services. Once [[Perestroika]] is initiated, then the Cold War restrictions no longer apply in the game.Handbook pp.59 The sequel ''[[Aerobiz Supersonic]]'' was released in August 1994 for the SNES and Mega Drive/Genesis. The player is presented with a wider variety of options in nearly everything, but the game play is much the same. Another sequel known as ''Air Management '96'' was released only in Japan for the [[Sega Saturn]] and [[PlayStation]].{{cite web|title=Air Management '96 Game Information|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/air-management-96|publisher=MobyGames|accessdate=12 June 2011}} ==Gameplay== Aerobiz features two timeframes to play the game through: 1963 to 1995, and 1983 to 2015. After selecting the timeframe, the players then choose a city for their airline's headquarters. This allows a certain amount of handicapping: some cities, such as [[New York City|New York]], [[London]], and [[Tokyo]], start the player with many airplanes and a large amount of money; others, such as [[Lima]], [[Nairobi]], and [[Honolulu]], start the player with only a couple of airplanes and a small amount of money. The players then select a difficulty level, which affects the number of passengers, world events (and the reactions of the passengers to those world events), and the win conditions. A charter system of independent airlines can have their shares bought or sold on the stock market; owning at least 51% of the company makes it eligible to be assimilated into the main airline.Handbook pp.48-49 The gameplay is superficially straightforward: players negotiate for access slots at each airport, buy airplanes, then open routes and start business. After each player has made their desired moves, the game shows any world events that affect the players (for instance, a labor strike will delay shipments of aircraft from that company, while the Olympic Games will boost traffic worldwide, particularly to the host city). The game then shows the results of direct competition between airlines flying the same routes, then the quarterly results of sales, expenses, profits, and passengers flown. After the January–March quarter of every year, it also shows annual results. There are elements of enhancing airline service, such as improving the convenience of arrivals/departures, along with reductions in fare, improving the quality of service along with advertising campaigns.Handbook pp.36-37, 40-47 The game is won by the first player to achieve the win conditions: link all 22 cities and carry a certain number of passengers (between 2.5 million and 4.5 million, based on difficulty level), all while remaining profitable. If a player goes for four quarters with a negative balance, the company is declared bankrupt and offered reorganization. If the game goes for 32 years (128 turns) without any player meeting the win conditions, the game is called a loss. {{Video game reviews |rev1 = ''[[MegaTech]]'' |rev1Score = 90%MegaTech rating, [[EMAP]], issue 21 |award1Pub = ''MegaTech'' |award1 = Hyper Game }} ''[[MegaTech]]'' magazine said the game had massive potential, and that "strategy buffs will cream over it". ===Scenarios=== ; Scenario 1 : This scenario starts in 1963 with the intense competition for the airlines heating up with aircraft that can fly for longer distances without re-fueling. All airlines are desperately trying to cross the long [[Pacific Ocean]] in the quest for intercontinental superiority.Handbook pp.12-13 ; Scenario 2 : This scenario starts in 1983 with the [[supersonic aircraft|supersonic airplane]] become the hottest topic in the airline industry.Handbook pp.14-15 ==Remake== {{Infobox video game |title = Air Management '96 |collapsible = yes |state = collapsed |image = |caption = |developer = [[Koei]] |publisher = Koei |series = ''[[Koei#Executive Series|Koei Executive Series]]'' |released = '''PlayStation:''' {{vgrelease|JP|March 22, 1996}} '''Sega Saturn:''' {{vgrelease|JP|March 22, 1996}} |genre = [[Business simulation game]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]]
[[multiplayer game|Multiplayer]] (up to four players) |platforms = [[PlayStation|Sony PlayStation]], [[Sega Saturn]], [[Microsoft Windows]] ([[Windows 95]] through [[Windows XP]]) }} A [[video game remake|remake]] of this game was made for the [[PlayStation|Sony PlayStation]], [[Sega Saturn]], and Windows PC called {{nihongo|'''''Air Management '96'''''|エアーマネジメント'96}}. Graphics have been enhanced in this version. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{Cite book | title = Air Management (Aerobiz) Handbook | series = Kou Shibusawa | year = 1992 | editor = Kou Shibusawa}} ==External links== *[http://www.gamefaqs.com/snes/563508-aerobiz/data ''Aerobiz'' (Super NES)] at GameFAQs *[http://www.gamefaqs.com/genesis/586012-aerobiz/data ''Aerobiz (Sega Genesis)] at GameFAQs *[http://www.gamefaqs.com/x68000/651089-air-management-oozora-ni-kakeru/data ''Air Management: Ōzora ni Kakeru'' (Sharp X68000)] at [[GameFAQs]] [[Category:1992 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Koei games]] [[Category:Sega Genesis games]] [[Category:Sharp X68000 games]] [[Category:NEC PC-9801 games]] [[Category:FM Towns games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games|Air Magagement 96']] [[Category:Sega Saturn games|Air Management 96']] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games set in Africa]] [[Category:Video games set in Asia]] [[Category:Video games set in Egypt]] [[Category:Video games set in Europe]] [[Category:Video games set in the Middle East]] [[Category:Video games set in North America]] [[Category:Video games set in South America]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Amado Boudou |image = Amado Boudou, 2009-07-08, en Casa Rosada (Buenos Aires).jpg |office = [[List of Vice Presidents of Argentina|Vice President of Argentina]] |president = [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] |term_start = 10 December 2011 |term_end = 10 December 2015 |predecessor = [[Julio Cobos]] |successor = [[Gabriela Michetti]] |office2 = [[Minister of Economy of Argentina|Minister of the Economy]] |president2 = [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] |term_start2 = 8 July 2009 |term_end2 = 10 December 2011 |predecessor2 = [[Carlos Rafael Fernández]] |successor2 = [[Hernán Lorenzino]] |office3 = Executive Director of [[ANSES]] |president3 = [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] |term_start3 = 5 May 2008 |term_end3 = 7 July 2009 |predecessor3 = Claudio Moroni |successor3 = [[Diego Bossio]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1962|11|19}} |birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina |nationality = [[Argentines|Argentine]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[UCeDé]]/[[Justicialist Party]]/[[Front for Victory]] |spouse = Daniela Andriuolo (1993–1998){{cite web|url=http://www.perfil.com/politica/La-historia-secreta-de-la-bailarina-que-se-caso-con-Boudou-pero-ya-no-lo-ama-20110708-0042.html|title=La historia secreta de la bailarina que se casó con Boudou pero ya no lo ama|date=8 July 2011|work=Diario Perfil}} | partner = Agustina Seguin (1996–2007){{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-207865-2012-11-15.html|title=La ex mujer de Boudou|date=15 November 2012|work=Página 12}}
Agustina Kämpfer (2009–){{cite web|url=http://www.lacapital.com.ar/informacion-gral/Boudou-y-Agustina-Kaumlmpfer-festejaron-su-noviazgo-en-Bariloche-20110908-0076.html|title=Boudou y Agustina Kämpfer festejaron su noviazgo en Bariloche|date=8 September 2011|work=La Capital}} |alma_mater = [[National University of Mar del Plata]]
[[University of CEMA|Center for Macroeconomic Studies of Argentina]] |signature = Firma Amado Boudou.svg }} '''Amado Boudou''' ({{IPA-es|aˈmaðo βuˈðu}}; born 19 November 1962) is an Argentine businessman and politician who served as the [[Vice President of Argentina]] from 2011 to 2015. He was previously [[Minister of Economy of Argentina|Minister of the Economy]] from 2009 to 2011. In August 2018, following a [[Boudougate|lengthy investigation]], he was convicted of corruption. He was then sentenced to five years and ten months in prison, and banned for life from holding public office.{{cite news |title=Argentina's former Vice-President Amado Boudou jailed for corruption |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-45104286 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC News |date=7 August 2018}} == Early life and career == Amado Boudou was born in [[Buenos Aires]], in 1962. His father, also named Amado, was born to a [[French Argentine|French immigrant]] from [[Aveyron]] named ''Aimé'', and this became a nickname for both.{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1149568-quien-es-amado-boudou|title=¿Quién es Amado Boudou?|work=La Nación}} He was raised in the ocean-front city of [[Mar del Plata]] and enrolled in the [[National University of Mar del Plata]], where he received a degree in economics, in 1986; described by acquaintances as a sociable type and fond of the bass guitar, he helped produce a number of rock concerts in Mar del Plata in his days as a student, including a festival attended by 15,000 spectators.[http://www.consejo.org.ar/Cv05/boudou_amado.htm Amado Boudou: curriculum vitae] {{es icon}} Boudou attended graduate courses in economics and was awarded a master's degree in economics by a private institution, the [[Universidad del CEMA|Argentine Macroeconomic Studies Center]] (CEMA), which is well-known locally for its support of [[neo-liberal]] and [[free market]] policies. Boudou was then brought in as a salesman by Venturino Ehisur S.A. (a local sanitation services company). Following his role in securing a number of lucrative hospital contracts for the company, he was named general manager in 1992 of their government contracts office. The company closed, however, when one of its top municipal clients terminated the contract in 1995.[http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2008/10/25/noticia_0015.html ''Perfil'' (25 October 2008)] {{es icon}} He then co-founded Ecoplata S.A., another sanitation services firm, and acted as its project manager; Ecoplata was awarded sanitation contracts by the resort cities of [[Villa Gesell]] and [[Pinamar]]. He married Daniela Andriuolo in 1993, but they were divorced five years later; they had no children. Boudou entered public service in 1998, when he was named to the Comptroller's Office of the National Social Security Administration ([[ANSES]]) by Economy Minister [[Roque Fernández]] (a fellow CEMA alumnus), and in February 2001, he was named that office's general manager. The election of [[Justicialist Party]] candidate Juan Pablo de Jesús as Mayor of the sea-side [[La Costa Partido|La Costa District]] resulted in Boudou's appointment as Finance Secretary for the popular resort district, which the policy maker accepted. The Finance Secretary subscribed to the 2005 Federal Housing Plan promulgated by President [[Néstor Kirchner]], a decision which made La Costa eligible for 486 low-income housing units. The contract, awarded to local builder Cantera FC in May 2005 for nearly US$10 million, was followed by Boudou's return to the ANSES, in January 2006. The Cantera FC contract resulted in an administrative debacle, however, when the builder abandoned the works in June 2007, having by then received over US$7 million in payments (for which the Mayor never initiated litigation). == National policy maker == Returned to the ANSES by its Director, [[Sergio Massa]], Boudou was named its Financial Director (a post second only to the director's in importance), and oversaw the voluntary conversion of several million private pension accounts to the ANSES' aegis when this choice was made available in December 2006. He was appointed its Director in October 2008, after Massa's promotion to the powerful post of Presidential Cabinet Chief. Boudou's appointment coincided with President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]]'s controversial decision to transfer loss-plagued private [[pension funds]]' assets of nearly US$30 billion to the ANSES, citing the cost of subsidizing 77% of the funds' beneficiaries and the effects of the [[Financial crisis of 2008|international crisis]] on the government's ability to obtain financing.[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2008/10/20/elpais/p-01785008.htm "Analizan cambios profundos en el sistema de jubilación privada"] ''Clarín'' (20 October 2008) {{es icon}} Following the ruling [[Front for Victory]]'s defeat in the June 2009 [[Argentine legislative election, 2009|mid-term elections]], Economy Minister [[Carlos Rafael Fernández]] tendered his resignation to the President, effective 7 July, and was replaced by the ANSES Director.[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2009/07/07/um/m-01954438.htm "Tras la dura derrota electoral, Cristina cambia medio Gabinete"], ''Clarín'' (7 July 2009) {{es icon}} Fallout from the international, [[2008 financial crisis]] later forced the left-wing Argentine government of President [[Cristina Kirchner]] to seek domestic financing for growing public spending, as well as for [[foreign debt]] service obligations. These policies and ongoing [[capital flight]] put further pressure on the [[Central Bank of Argentina|Central Bank]]'s ability to finance debt service obligations, and the president ordered a US$6.7 billion account opened at the Central Bank for the latter purpose in December 2009, implying the use of the Central Bank's [[foreign exchange reserve]]s, and drawing direct opposition from the institution's President, [[Martín Redrado]]; Redrado was ultimately forced to resign.[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2010/01/22/um/m-02125286.htm "Aníbal Fernández: 'Redrado no entra más al Banco Central'"], ''Clarín'' (22 January 2010) {{es icon}} Boudou presented a [[Debt restructuring|debt swap]] package on 3 May 2010, for the holders of over US$18 billion in bonds who did not participate in the 2005 [[Argentine debt restructuring]] prepared by former Economy Minister [[Roberto Lavagna]].[http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2010/5/3/un-487506.asp ''Los Andes'' (3 May 2010)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/63mtJIrUB?url=http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2010/5/3/un-487506.asp |date=8 December 2011 }} {{es icon}} These [[Holdout problem|holdouts]] include numerous [[vulture fund]]s which had eschewed the 2005 offer, and had instead resorted to the courts in a bid for higher returns on their defaulted bonds. These disputes had led to a number of liens against central bank accounts in New York and, indirectly, to reduced Argentine access to international credit markets.[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2010/01/12/um/m-02118566.htm "Embargaron fondos del Central en EE.UU. y el Gobierno volvió a denunciar maniobras desestabilizadoras"], ''Clarín'' (12 January 2010) {{es icon}} In October 2010 Boudou compared Candelaria de la Sota and Martín Kanenguiser, journalists from ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'' and ''[[La Nación]]'', with the people cleaning the gas chambers during the [[Holocaust]].[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1313281 Agresión de Boudou a periodistas] {{es icon}} Kanenguiser requested clarification, but Boudou instead defended his statement.[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1314013 La agresión de Boudou a periodistas fue un agravio para toda la sociedad] {{es icon}} His attack was condemned by the FOPEA (an organization of journalists), members of the legislature,[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1314035 Críticas a Boudou por la agresión a dos periodistas] {{es icon}} and the [[DAIA]].[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1313539 Unánime rechazo al ministro] {{es icon}} The DAIA accused him of trivializing the holocaust, and Congressman [[Eduardo Amadeo]] demanded his resignation; Boudou later stated that this was a badly chosen metaphor.[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1314115 "Se trató de una metáfora inadecuada", dijo Boudou tras la agresión a periodistas] {{es icon}} The Economy Minister announced his bid for the office of [[Mayor of Buenos Aires]] in December 2010 as a candidate in the [[Front for Victory]] primaries ahead of the 2011 race; hoping to solidify his base among the country's influential trade unions, he made the announcement at the headquarters of SMATA (the machinists' and auto workers' union).[http://www.elargentino.com/nota-119189-Boudou-lanza-su-candidatura-a-Jefe-de-Gobierno.html ''El Argentino'': Boudou lanza su precandidatura a Jefe de Gobierno] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723093419/http://www.elargentino.com/nota-119189-Boudou-lanza-su-candidatura-a-Jefe-de-Gobierno.html |date=23 July 2011 }} {{es icon}} Ultimately, however, Senator [[Daniel Filmus]] was nominated in May.{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1375035-elecciones-en-la-capital-reunion-en-olivos-para-definir-candidatos|title=Filmus-Tomada, la fórmula kirchnerista para la Capital|work=La Nación}} == Vice-Presidency == [[File:Amado Boudou y Cristina Fernández de Kirchner 2011-12-10.jpg|thumb|Boudou and [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] at her 2011 inauguration]] Boudou was nominated as running mate on President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]]'s [[Front for Victory]] ticket for the [[Argentine general election, 2011|2011 elections]].{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/politica/elecciones/elecciones_2011-candidato_a_vicepresidente-acto_Olivos-companero_formula_Cristina_0_505749697.html|title=Cristina eligió a Boudou como su compañero de fórmula|work=Clarín}} Boudou's role in the campaign was noted for his numerous performances at rallies with his bass guitar, and as a DJ.{{cite web|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-174015-2011-08-08.html|title=Boudou con las bandejas de DJ|work=Página/12|date=8 August 2011}} They won the October general election with 54% of the vote. Vice President Boudou assumed presidential duties for twenty days on 4 January 2012, while President Fernández de Kirchner underwent a [[thyroidectomy]] and convalesced.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-16342685|title=Argentina President Cristina Fernandez has cancer|publisher=BBC News|date=28 December 2011}} Boudou again assumed presidential duties for 42 days{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-24906559|title=Argentine president expected to return to work next week|publisher=BBC News|date=11 November 2013}} on 8 October 2013, while President Fernández de Kirchner underwent surgery to relieve [[Subarachnoid hemorrhage|bleeding on her brain]] and convalesced.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-24438437|title=Argentina President Cristina Fernandez surgery 'went well'|publisher=BBC News|date=8 October 2013}} === Trial and conviction === {{Main|Boudougate}} The vice president faced accusations of [[influence peddling]] in 2012 regarding contracts awarded by the Economy Ministry to Ciccone Printing for the supply of 100 peso bills, license plates, and other government issues. The controversy arose following statements made by the ex-wife of Ciccone executive Alejandro Vanderbroele to the effect that Boudou was his [[Sleeping partner|silent partner]] in the firm. It was alleged that [[César Guido Forcieri]], who had previously worked under Boudou, had made the connection between the two men. Pursuant to prosecutor Carlos Rívolo's request and following news that the [[Puerto Madero]] condominium rented by Boudou was owned by a friend of Vanderbroele who had, moreover, borrowed funds from Boudou, Judge Daniel Rafecas ordered the residence searched for proof of business associations between Vanderbroele and the vice president;{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/politica/Allanaron-Amado-Boudou-Puerto-Madero_0_676132617.html|title=Operativo judicial en un departamento de Boudou|work=Clarín}} a receipt for one month of [[homeowner association]] dues owed by the condominium's owner, Fabián Carosso, and paid instead by Vanderbroele was located in the search on 4 April.{{cite web|url=http://www.infonews.com/2012/04/04/politica-16779-otra-operacion-de-clarin-vandenbroele-no-pago-expensas-de-boudou.php|title=Otra operación de Clarín: Vandenbroele no pagó expensas de Boudou|work=Info News|date=4 April 2012}} Following an August 2013 judicial ruling ordering prosecutors to provide evidence of wrongdoing, and their subsequent failure to do so, on 11 September a Federal Court granted a motion by Boudou's attorneys that would allow them to file for a [[Nolle prosequi|dismissal of charges]].{{cite web|url=http://www.perfil.com/politica/Guio-judicial-a-Boudou-podria-pedir-su-sobreseimiento-en-el-caso-Ciccone-20130911-0025.html|title=Guiño judicial a Boudou: podría pedir su sobreseimiento en el caso Ciccone|work=Perfil|date=11 September 2013}} He was, however, indicted on [[Bribery#Forms of bribery|passive bribery]] and influence peddling charges by Judge Ariel Lijo on 27 June 2014; Boudou appealed the indictment on 10 July, alleging [[malicious prosecution]].{{cite web|url=http://buenosairesherald.com/article/164256/vp-amado-boudou-files-appeal-against-corruption-indictment|title=VP Amado Boudou files appeal against corruption indictment|work=Buenos Aires Herald|date=10 July 2014}} Boudou is also being investigated for several other offenses and/or crimes, and is a defendant in a total of ten cases in the Federal Courts.[http://www.perfil.com/politica/Boudou-suma-diez-causas-en-la-Justicia-federal-20140629-0053.html Boudou suma diez causas en la Justicia federal], Perfil, 29 June 2014 (Spanish) On 3 November 2017, Boudou was arrested on charges of [[money laundering]] and [[racketeering]], during the ongoing trial.{{cite news|title=Ex-Argentina VP Boudou arrested in corruption case|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-argentina-corruption/ex-argentina-vp-boudou-arrested-in-corruption-case-idUSKBN1D317J|accessdate=4 November 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|date=3 November 2017}} The case was ended in August 2018, and he was sentenced to five years and ten months. He has also been banned for life from holding public office.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/argentina-s-former-vp-boudou-convicted-of-corruption/4517781.html|title=Argentina's Former VP Boudou Convicted of Corruption|work=Voice of America|date=7 August 2018}} Nicolás Ciccone, former owner of Ciccone Printing, was also sentenced to four years and six months.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-45104286|title=Argentina's former Vice-President Amado Boudou jailed for corruption|author=|date=7 August 2018|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 August 2018}} He is jailed at a prison in [[Ezeiza, Buenos Aires|Ezeiza]], alongside other inmates also convicted for corruption cases during the Kirchner government, such as [[José López scandal|José López]] and [[Lázaro Báez]].{{cite web|url=https://www.clarin.com/politica/rutina-presos-carcel-ezeiza_0_ry5zr2PHm.html|title=Amado Boudou preso: cómo es la rutina de los presos K en la cárcel de Ezeiza|trans-title= Amado Boudou, prisoner: which is the routine of the prisoners K in the Ezeiza prison|language=Spanish|author=|date=7 August 2018|publisher=Clarín|accessdate=8 August 2018}} Boudou claims that he is a victim of political persecution. He said that the "alleged bribe has no basis or link to the evidence because it didn’t exist."{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/08/08/world/politics-diplomacy-world/argentine-ex-vice-president-amado-boudou-convicted-corruption-former-president-cristina-kirchner/#.W2s7S9ThBkg|title=Argentine ex-Vice President Amado Boudou convicted for corruption under former President Cristina Kirchner|author=|date=8 August 2018|publisher=The Japan Times|accessdate=8 August 2018}} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Amado Boudou}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Carlos Rafael Fernández]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Minister of Economy of Argentina|Minister of the Economy]]|years=2009–2011}} {{s-aft|after=[[Hernán Lorenzino]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Julio Cobos]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of Vice Presidents of Argentina|Vice President of Argentina]]|years=2011–2015}} {{s-aft|after=[[Gabriela Michetti]]}} {{s-end}} {{CFK cabinet 1}} {{CFK cabinet 2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boudou, Amado}} [[Category:Vice Presidents of Argentina]] [[Category:Argentine Ministers of Finance]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Argentine economists]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]] [[Category:Justicialist Party politicians]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Politicians from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Argentine people of French descent]] [[Category:21st-century Argentine politicians]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Argentina]] [[Category:Politicians convicted of corruption]] [[Category:Argentine politicians convicted of crimes]]

{{Infobox person | image = AndrewFlipFilipowski.jpg | | image_size = 150px | | name = Andrew J. "Flip" Filipowski | caption = | birth_date = 1950 | birth_place = [[Chicago, IL]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Technology Entrepreneur }}
'''Andrew J. "Flip" Filipowski''' is a [[Poland|Polish]] American technology entrepreneur born in 1950 in [[Chicago, IL|Chicago]]. He is currently the Executive Chairman and CEO of SilkRoad Equity, a private investment firm, and founded [[Platinum Technology|Platinum technology]] in 1987. He is also currently the Co-CEO of [http://www.flur.ee Fluree PBC], a blockchain database technology company. He also founded and is the Chairman of VeriBlock a leading technology company that provides Bitcoin security to the world's blockchain. He founded or co-founded [[Blue Rhino|Blue Rhino Corporation]], Primo Water, SilkRoad technology Inc., DBMS Inc., the [[House of Blues]], SolidSpace Inc., Onramp Branding, MissionMode, Unocoin and InterAct 911.<ref>[http://www.interact911.com/andrew-flip-filipowski-biography/ InterAct - Andrew Filipowski Biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523221652/http://www.interact911.com/andrew-flip-filipowski-biography/ |date=May 23, 2013 }}</ref> Platinum technology was sold to [[Computer Associates]] in 1999 for $4 billion, a record at the time for a software company.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.crn.com/it-channel/18803143 |title=CA To Buy Platinum For $3.5 Billion |publisher=CRN |accessdate=2007-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927232050/http://www.crn.com/it-channel/18803143 |archivedate=2007-09-27 }}</ref> Filipowski's personal proceeds from the deal were $290 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/01/business/private-sector-a-maverick-has-plans-for-chicago.html?pagewanted=all|title= PRIVATE SECTOR; A Maverick Has Plans for Chicago|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2008-06-16 | first=David | last=Barboza | date=1999-08-01}}</ref>
Filipowski founded or served in an executive capacity in a number of companies including [[Divine (corporation)|divine, inc.]], DBMS, Inc. and [[Cullinet]] Corp; he also served in various managerial and technical positions with A.B. Dick, [[Motorola]] and [[Time, Inc]]. Throughout the course of his career, Filipowski, along with his management team, has acquired and integrated nearly 200 public and private companies.
Filipowski was the 1998 recipient of the [[Anti-Defamation League]]'s Torch of Liberty Award, first for the [[Silicon Prairie]] (Chicago), for his support in fighting hate on the Internet.
In 2000, he was named one of the 100 most influential individuals in the technology field in [[Upside (magazine)|''Upside'' magazine]]’s 2000 Upside Elite 100 list.
Flip is a futurist and renowned speaker on such topics as Bitcoin, Crypto Assets, Blockchain, FinTech, History of Money, Energy, Disruption, Venture Capital, Entrepreneurship, Digital Autonomous Organizations, and Organizational Structures. Flip is a resource for YPO/WPO and has recently keynoted at Blockchain events in Kenya, Kazakhstan, Toronto and at industry events such as the Blockchain Cruise Asia 2018, North America Bitcoin Conference, Blockchain Nation among others
==References== <references/>

page.title: Charles Innes-Ker, Marquess of Bowmont and Cessford

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Marquess of Bowmont and Cessford | birth_name = | birth_date = {{bda|1981|2|18|df=y}} | birth_place = | education = [[Eton College]]
[[Newcastle University|University of Newcastle upon Tyne]]
[[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]] | occupation = | yearsactive = | spouse = {{marriage|Hon. Charlotte Aitken|2011|2012|end=div}} | parents = [[Guy Innes-Ker, 10th Duke of Roxburghe]]
Lady Jane Grosvenor | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{flag|United Kingdom}} | branch = {{army|UK}} | serviceyears = | serviceyears_label = | rank = [[Captain (United Kingdom)|Captain]] | rank_label = | servicenumber = | unit = [[Blues and Royals]] | battles = }} }} '''Captain Charles Robert George Innes Ker, Marquess of Bowmont and Cessford''' (born 18 February 1981), is a British aristocrat. ==Biography== Lord Bowmont is the eldest son and [[heir apparent]] of the [[Guy Innes-Ker, 10th Duke of Roxburghe|10th Duke of Roxburghe]] and his first wife, the former Lady Jane Meriel Grosvenor, daughter of the [[Robert Grosvenor, 5th Duke of Westminster|5th Duke of Westminster]].Tom O'Sullivan, [https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2000/mar/12/rich.life11 The young elite 11-20], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 12 March 2000 His uncle was [[Gerald Grosvenor, 6th Duke of Westminster]]. He was educated at [[Eton College]] and the [[Newcastle University|University of Newcastle upon Tyne]]. He attended the [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]], passed out in December 2004, and has served with the [[Blues and Royals]] in [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]] and [[Iraq]]. He will inherit [[Floors Castle]] and 60,000 acres around the [[Cheviot Hills]] and the [[River Tweed]] as well as [[hotel]]s in the area, leading up to an estimated wealth of £100 million. In February 2003, he was caught travelling on the [[Tyne and Wear Metro]] without paying the £1 fare.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2003/02/07/ndodge07.xml |title=''Daily Telegraph'', 7 February 2003 - Student heir to £70m dodges £1 rail fare |accessdate=25 July 2011 |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Andrew |last=Haldenby |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311055244/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2003%2F02%2F07%2Fndodge07.xml |archivedate=11 March 2007 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/england/2753825.stm| title = ''BBC News'', 12 February 2003 - Marquess pays up after dodging fare| accessdate = 25 July 2011 | date=12 February 2003}} He chose to pay a £10 fine rather than take the case to court and risk appearing on "losers' posters" displayed around the city, naming people who had been caught travelling without tickets. ==Personal life== On 22 July 2011, he married [[The Honourable]] Charlotte Susanna Aitken (b. 15 February 1982), eldest daughter of [[Maxwell Aitken, 3rd Baron Beaverbrook]].{{cite news | url = http://announcements.telegraph.co.uk/marriages/136119/the-marquis-of-bowmont-and-cessford-and-the-hon-charlotte-aitken| title = Telegraph Announcements - The Marquis of Bowmont and Cessford and the Hon Charlotte Aitken| accessdate = 25 July 2011 | location=London| work=The Daily Telegraph}} The couple split and sued for divorce in June 2012, less than a year after the wedding.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2157059/Dukes-son-Charlie-ends-marriage-year.html] ===Chiefship of Clan Innes=== The present Duke of Roxburghe is heir to the chiefship of the Clan Innes (Clann Innis, '''not''' ''Mac Aonghuis'' or Clan MacInnes); however, since he bears the surname Innes-Ker, the [[Lord Lyon King of Arms]] will not recognise him as chief of the name Innes. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Charles Innes-Ker, Marquess of Bowmont and Cessford''' |2= 2. [[Guy Innes-Ker, 10th Duke of Roxburghe]] |3= 3. Lady Jane Grosvenor |4= 4. [[George Innes-Ker, 9th Duke of Roxburghe]] |5= 5. Margaret McConnel |6= 6. [[Robert Grosvenor, 5th Duke of Westminster]] |7= 7. [[Viola Grosvenor, Duchess of Westminster|The Hon. Viola Lyttelton]] |8= 8. [[Henry Innes-Ker, 8th Duke of Roxburghe]] |9= 9. [[Mary Goelet]] |10= 10. Frederick McConnel |11= 11. Frances Pringle |12= 12. [[Lord Hugh Grosvenor]] |13= 13. Lady Mabel Crichton |14= 14. [[John Lyttelton, 9th Viscount Cobham]] |15= 15. Violet Leonard |16= 16. [[James Innes-Ker, 7th Duke of Roxburghe]] |17= 17. [[Anne Innes-Ker, Duchess of Roxburghe|Lady Anne Spencer-Churchill]] |18= 18. [[Ogden Goelet]] |19= 19. Mary Wilson |20= 20. William McConnel |21= 21. Margaret Wanklyn |22= 22. |23= 23. |24= 24. [[Hugh Grosvenor, 1st Duke of Westminster]] |25= 25. The Hon. Katherine Cavendish |26= 26. [[John Crichton, 4th Earl Erne]] |27= 27. Lady Florence Cole |28= 28. [[Charles Lyttelton, 8th Viscount Cobham]] |29= 29. The Hon. Mary Cavendish |30= 30. Charles Leonard |31= 31. Catherine Le Seur }} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{British courtesy marquesses}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Innes-Ker, Charles Robert George}} [[Category:British courtesy marquesses|Bowmont]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College|Bowmont, Charles Innes-Ker, Marquess of]] [[Category:Alumni of Newcastle University|Bowmont, Charles Innes-Ker, Marquess of]] [[Category:British people of American descent]] [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Blues and Royals officers]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Iraq War]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]] [[Category:Goelet family]] {{UK-noble-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Cherry Bekaert LLP | logo = Corporate logo for Cherry Bekaert LLP.png | logo_size = 200px | type = [[Limited Liability Partnership]] | foundation = {{Start date|1947}}, [[Wilmington, North Carolina]] | location = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | area_served = [[Southeast United States]] | key_people = Michelle L. Thompson (Firm Managing Partner & CEO) | industry = [[Professional services]] | services = [[Audit]]
[[Tax]]
[[Assurance services|Assurance]]
[[Wealth Management]] | revenue = [[United States dollar|US$]]173.8 million (2018) | num_employees = More than 1,150 (2018) | homepage = [http://www.cbh.com/ cbh.com] }} '''Cherry Bekaert LLP''' (formerly Cherry, Bekaert & Holland L.L.P.) is the second largest certified public accounting firm headquartered in the Southeast United States and one of the Top 30 accounting firms in the United States.''Accounting Today/Bloomberg Tax'', [https://www.pragermetis.com/sites/pragermetis.com/files/Accounting-Today-Top-100-Accounting-Firms.pdf] With offices located in Maryland, Virginia, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, Rhode Island, Texas, Tennessee, and South Carolina,[http://cbh.com/about/locations.asp Cherry Bekaert LLP Locations] Cherry Bekaert ranks in the top 30 US accounting firms.[https://www.pragermetis.com/sites/pragermetis.com/files/Accounting-Today-Top-100-Accounting-Firms.pdf Accounting Today Top 100 Accounting Firms] Employing nearly 1160 professionals, Cherry Bekaert reported revenues of $173.80 million in 2018. Cherry Bekaert LLP is a founding member of [[Baker Tilly International]],''Hoovers'', [http://www.hoovers.com/company/Cherry_Bekaert__Holland_L_L_P/rtkchti-1.html Cherry, Bekaert & Holland, L.L.P.] a network of 149 independent firms in 125 countries worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.bakertillyinternational.com/|title=A leading network of like-minded independent accountancy and business advisory firms - Baker Tilly International|first=Baker Tilly|last=International|website=www.bakertillyinternational.com}} ==History== [[File:Cbh vienna office.jpg|thumb|alt=Cherry Bekaert Office, Vienna, VA|Cherry Bekaert offices, Vienna, VA.]]Cherry Bekaert began in 1947 as a small practice in Wilmington, North Carolina, led by Harry Cherry.''Star News'', July 11, 1971 [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6LksAAAAIBAJ&sjid=swkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6653,1869321&dq=cherry+bekaert+and+holland+history&hl=en Names that made the news in SENCland] Charles Bekaert and William Holland joined the Firm in 1952 and 1953 respectively.[http://www.cbh.com/news/pressreleases_details.asp?id=69 Cherry, Bekaert & Holland Celebrates 60th Anniversary as a Firm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708124627/http://www.cbh.com/news/pressreleases_details.asp?id=69 |date=July 8, 2011 }} The Firm moved into the Richmond, Virginia, area in 1988, eventually relocating the corporate headquarters to Richmond from Charlotte in 1991.Charlotte Observer - September 12, 1991 - 1D BUSINESS, [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CO&s_site=charlotte&p_multi=CO&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB6C8466AFF4FFC&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM ACCOUNTING FIRM WILL MOVE TO RICHMOND] Beginning May 1, 2018, Michelle Thompson succeeded Howard Kies as Cherry Bekaert's Firm Managing Partner and Chief Executive Officer.[http://www.cbh.com/about/news/cherry-bekaert-elects-michelle-l-thompson-as-firm-managing-partner/] ==Services== * Assurance{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/services/assurance-accounting/|title=Assurance - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Advisory{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/services/advisory-services/|title=Advisory - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Tax{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/services/tax-services/|title=Tax - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Wealth Management{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/services/wealth-management/|title=Home - Cherry Bekaert Wealth Management LLC|website=www.cbh.com}} ==Industries== Cherry Bekaert LLP is divided into twelve industry groups, including:{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/|title=Industries - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Education{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/education/|title=Education - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Financial Services{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/financial-services/|title=Financial Services - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Government{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/government/|title=Government - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Government Contractors{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/government-contractors/|title=Government Contractors - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Healthcare{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/healthcare/|title=Healthcare - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Industrial{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/manufacturing-distribution/|title=Industrial - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Nonprofits{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/non-profits/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141211000614/http://www.cbh.com/industries/non-profits/ |archivedate=2014-12-11 |df= }} * Professional Services{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/professional-services/|title=Professional Services - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Real Estate & Construction{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/real-estate-and-construction/|title=Real Estate & Construction - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Retail & Restaurant{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/retail-restaurants/|title=Retail & Restaurants - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Technology and Health & Life Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/technology-and-life-sciences/|title=Technology and Health & Life Sciences - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} * Transportation & Logistics{{cite web|url=http://www.cbh.com/industries/transportation-logistics/|title=Transportation & Logistics - Tax, Audit and Advisory Services|website=www.cbh.com}} ==Firm Accolades== Cherry Bekaert has been recognized as one of the "Best Places to Work" by job search site Vault.com;{{cite web|url=http://www.vault.com/wps/portal/usa/companies/company-profile?companyId=38430&WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/wps/wcm/connect/Vault_Content_Library/companies+site/companies/parent_cherry++bekaert+_+holland+llp/cherry++bekaert+_+holland+llp_0/cherry++bekaert+_+holland+llp_0|title=Cherry Bekaert LLP-Company Profile-Vault.com|publisher=}} ''Inside Business'' in Hampton Roads, VA;[https://archive.is/20120721044855/http://www.cbh.com/email/pressrelease/pr-HRbptw09.html CB&H Again Named Among "Top Places to Work" in Virginia Beach by ''Inside Business''] ''Triangle Business Journal'' in Raleigh, NC;[http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2008/09/29/focus6.html CB&H Again Named Best Place to Work by the ''Triangle Business Journal''] and ''Tampa Bay Business Journal'' in Tampa Bay, FL.[http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/stories/2009/03/09/daily22.html CB&H Named to ''Tampa Bay Business Journal's'' 2009 Best Places to Work List] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.cbh.com/ }} * [http://www.bakertillyinternational.com/web/home.aspx Baker Tilly International Official Website] * [http://cbhwealth.com/ Cherry Bekaert LLP Wealth Management Official Website] [[Category:Accounting firms of the United States]] [[Category:Baker Tilly]] [[Category:Organizations based in Richmond, Virginia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Cone Mills Corporation | logo = | fate = [[Bankruptcy]] | successor = [[International Textile Group]] | foundation = 1895 | defunct = 2004 | location = [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] | industry = [[Textiles]] | key_people = [[Moses H. Cone]] | products = [[denim]], [[corduroy]], [[flannel]] | num_employees = appx 10,000 | parent = | subsid = }} '''Cone Mills Corporation''' was a world leader in [[textile manufacturing]] of [[corduroy]], [[flannel]], [[denim]] and other [[cotton]] fabrics for most of the 20th century. The company was based in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] and its mills were mostly in [[North Carolina|North]] and [[South Carolina]]. The company was known as the world's largest producer of [[denim]].[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Cone-Mills-LLC-Company-History.html Cone Mills LLC - company history]; [http://www.secinfo.com/dMX7.21u.d.htm Cone Mills Corporation current report 2003 Form 8-K News Release]; [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE0D71430F930A35751C0A967958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all All About/Denim; The Appeal of Blue -- Now Red or Green -- Jeans][http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/39/Cone-Mills-Corporation.html Cone Mills Corporation - Company Profile, Information, Business Description, History, Background Information on Cone Mills Corporation] It was disestablished in 2004. ==Early history== [[File:Proximity White Oak plant Greensboro.jpg|right|thumb|One of the first company cotton mill plants, ca. 1900]] The Cone family history begins in 1845 when Herman Kahn (1828–1897), a [[History of the Jews in Germany|Jewish-German]] [[immigrant]], and his sister’s family left their home in [[Bavaria, Germany]] for a new life in the United States. Herman changed the spelling of his last name from ''Kahn'' to "Cone" almost immediately upon arrival in the United States to become more [[United States|American]].Noblitt p. 4 Herman Cone and his brother-in-law Jacob Adler started a [[dry goods]] business in the German-speaking [[Pennsylvania Dutch]] town of [[Jonesboro, Tennessee]]. Cone & Adler sold the usual items like groceries, hats, boots, and shoes. An exception to this was that they also sold ready-to-wear clothing, unusual in the antebellum South where most clothing was made at home.Noblitt, p. 5 Herman met Helen Guggenheimer (1838–1898) in one of his business traveling trips to [[Lynchburg, Virginia]] in the early part of the 1850s. She was also from Germany and was Jewish. In 1856, when Helen was eighteen, they got married. Their first child was [[Moses H. Cone]], born in 1857, founder of Proximity Manufacturing Company (original name for the Cone Mills [[Business|enterprises]]). Their next was Ceasar, born in 1859, the co-founder. The family showed in the [[American Civil War|pre-Civil War]] 1860 census that their real estate holdings and personal property holdings were an impressive $29,365. By 1861 they closed their business because of the war and put their money instead into real estate.Noblitt p. 6 At the end of the war, the family sold some of their real estate to reopen their retail business under the name ''Adler, Cone, and Shipley.'' [[File:Division of Cone Mills with mill village 1914.jpg|thumb|left|A division of Cone Mills with a mill village, ca. 1914]] They engaged in the [[barter]] system to trade goods, since cash was then very scarce. They traded their goods for textiles and then resold these in the [[Southern United States|South]] for cash. Many times they just took credit on personal property and land. They foreclosed on many of the debts owed them, acquiring hundreds of acres of real estate in the process.Noblitt, p. 6 In 1870 the family, who at this point was fairly wealthy, moved to [[Baltimore, Maryland]] and started a wholesale grocery business called ''Guggenheimer, Cone & Company.'' The family at this point had seven children, five boys and two girls, Claribel and Etta, who gained a reputation as the art-collecting [[Cone sisters]].Noblitt, p. 7 This business owned by several relative members was ultimately disbanded in 1873 and Herman went into business with his eldest sons, Moses and Ceasar. This new firm was called ''H. Cone & Sons.'' The two eldest, Moses and Ceasar, worked with their father in his grocery business while in their teens traveling the [[Southern United States|Southeast]] as "drummers" (traveling salesmen). The brothers took and bartered orders from southern merchants for their father's [[Product (business)|wares]]. By 1876 the business had expanded to include tobacco and leather goods.Noblitt, p. 8 [[File:Interior of a cotton mill 1909.jpg|thumb|Interior of a North Carolina cotton mill, ca. 1909]] In 1887, Moses and Ceasar Cone invested $50,000 in the C. E. Graham Mill Manufacturing Company of [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. They manufactured cotton [[Tartan|plaid]]s. In 1893 the mill became Asheville Cotton Mills. In 1888, the brothers invested in Salisbury Cotton Mills of [[Salisbury, North Carolina]]. They also invested in Minneola Manufacturing Company of [[Gibsonville, North Carolina]]. In 1891, Moses and Ceasar Cone established the Cone Export & Commission Company. The selling agent for southern textiles was called a "plaid trust" by its competitors. Chartered in New Jersey, the company's headquarters were located in [[New York City]] and Moses served as its president. In 1893, the Cone brothers then built one of the first textile [[finishing (textiles)|finishing]] plants in the South, called Southern Finishing & Warehouse Company. Moses Cone built his first denim manufacturing plant in Greensboro in 1895. The plant was called the Proximity Cotton Mills because of its location to the nearby cotton fields.[http://www.proximityhotel.com/history.htm The History of Proximity Cotton Mill and Proximity Print Works] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225052403/http://www.proximityhotel.com/history.htm |date=2008-02-25 }} Near the mills "Brother Moses" and "Brother Ceasar" built a facility to serve as the company's headquarters. Ceasar was its first president.[http://www.blowingrock.org/mosescone.html Moses H. Cone Memorial Park] The Cone family, many of whom later were involved in Moses and Ceasar's enterprises, included Carrie (1861–1927), Monroe (1862–1891), Claribel (1864–1929), Albert (1866–1867), Solomon (1868–1939), Sydney M. (1869–1939), Etta (1870–1949), Julius W. (1872–1940), Bernard M. (1874–1956), Clarence N. (1876–1929), and Frederick W. (1878-1944). == Turn of the century == [[File:White Oak Mills Greensboro NC 1909.jpg|thumb|White Oak Mills in Greensboro, North Carolina, ca. 1909]] In 1899 Moses and Ceasar partnered with Emanuel and Herman Sternberger of South Carolina to build a [[flannel]] production plant called Revolution Mills. In 1905 under Proximity Manufacturing Company the Cone brothers built White Oak Cotton Mills in Greensboro. By 1908 it was the world's largest producer of denim.Noblitt, p. 18[https://books.google.com/books?id=ep6FZsDQyJMC&pg=PA205&dq=phil+noblitt+cone+mill&sig=wQ_IS8Zc7x4yCKvpklFOAV322LA#PPA18,M1 A Mansion in the Mountains by Philip Noblitt - page 18] The heavy-duty blue denim manufactured by the mills controlled by Moses gave him the reputation of being "the Denim King."Renour, p. 74[http://www.virtualblueridge.com/parkway_tour/parks/293_0/ Blue Ridge Parkway Foundation - The Moses H. Cone Memorial Park]; [http://www.metronc.com/article/?id=419 MetroMagazine's NC Business Hall of Fame] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060510093512/http://www.metronc.com/article/?id=419 |date=2006-05-10 }} The company has produced the denim fabric for [[Levi Strauss & Co.|Levi Strauss & Company]] since 1915. They are the exclusive supplier in recent years of the fabric for Levi's brand 501 jeans.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_1997_May_15/ai_19421835 Cone Mills Corporation chooses BPCS Client/Server version 6.0 to streamline order fulfillment process] In 1912 the company opened Proximity Print Works. This plant was one of the earliest color cloth printing facilities in the [[Southern United States]]. In 1927 the company acquired Cliffside Cotton Mills (manufacturer of [[terry cloth]]) and Haynes Plant (producer of [[chambray]]). By 1929 they had acquired Holt-Granite Puritan Mills Company of [[Haw River, North Carolina]]. They then acquired the [[corduroy]] producing Tabardrey Manufacturing Company. By 1932 the Cone company had gained controlling stock of Eno Cotton Mills of [[Hillsborough, North Carolina]]. They bought the Florence Mills of [[Forest City, North Carolina]] in 1941 and also its subsidiary called American Spinning Company of [[Greenville, South Carolina]]. == Company changes name == In 1945 the company merged all its separate mill properties into the Proximity Manufacturing Company. The manufacturing companies, mills, and various subsidiaries owned by the Cones underwent a major reorganization in which the separate business operations of Proximity Manufacturing Company (including Proximity Cotton Mills, Proximity Print Works, White Oak, and Granite), the Cliffside Mills (including the Cliffside and Haynes plants), the Florence Mills (including American Spinning Company), Minneola Manufacturing Company, Salisbury Cotton Mills, Tabardrey Manufacturing Company, and Cone Export & Commission Company, were all reorganized. Then in 1948 another major merger occurred. Revolution Mills and Proximity Manufacturing Company was consolidated and named Cone Mills Corporation. In 1950 the company announced a merger with the twill and drill manufacturer Dwight Manufacturing Company of Alabama. The following year it purchased the company outright, being the same year the Corporation went public trading on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. Cone Mills Corporation in 1952 purchased the Union Bleachery of Greenville, South Carolina. They then gained the first license for the [[Sanforization|sanforizing]] process granted in the United States. == Involvement with other organizations == [[File:Cone Memorial YMCA.jpg|thumb|Cone Memorial YMCA
( White Oak Branch )]] Cone Mills Corporation was involved with Cone Memorial YMCA (the White Oak, Proximity, and segregated branches), Camp Herman, night school, and employment of nurses. They built housing near their mills, both boarding houses and single family homes. Stores sold dairy products and meat was produced on company farms. The company built a school and donated land for churches for each village. The company also instituted a Welfare Office. They were also involved with state and regional cotton and textile associations, the Mill Workers Mutual Benefit Association, and Summit Avenue Building Company. The company was also associated with the Cone Country Club and founded the [[Moses H. Cone Memorial Hospital]]. From 1958 to 1969 they were involved with the annual [[Miss North Carolina|Miss North Carolina Pageant]]. The company provided fabric for wardrobes that were given to each year's winner. They also provided fabric for the presentation gown that each winner wore to represent North Carolina in the annual [[Miss America Pageant]].[http://www.lib.unc.edu/mss/inv/c/Cone_Mills_Corporation.html Inventory of the Cone Mills Corporation Records, 1858-1997] == White Oak Closure == ITG ([[International Textile Group]]), parent company of Cone Denim, announced in 2017 that after more than 110 years of continuous production its White Oak mill in [[Greensboro, North Carolina|Greensboro]] will cease operations. The company worked closely with its White Oak customers to fulfill all orders and meet customer needs over the coming months, including transitioning styles to its other global platforms as ITG continues to be headquartered in [[Greensboro, NC]] with ten manufacturing operations across the U.S., Mexico and China. {{Cite news|url=https://www.sportswear-international.com/news/stories/Closure-Sad-denim-days-ITV-and-Cone-Denim-White-Oak-facility-to-close-down-13734|title=Closure: Sad denim days: ITV and Cone Denim’s White Oak facility to close down|work=sportswear-international.com|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/westernbonime/2017/11/26/tellason-denim-and-america-why-the-white-oaks-closure-matters/#1fc23abf254d|title=Tellason, Denim And America, Why The White Oaks Closure Matters|last=Bonime|first=Western|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en}} When the mill closed, it was the last large scale denim mill to shut in the USA, meaning you could no longer get American made selvedge denim.{{Cite news|url=https://www.heddels.com/2017/10/cone-mills-close-white-oak-plant-last-american-selvedge-denim-mill/|title=Cone Mills to Close White Oak Plant, Last American Selvedge Denim Mill|date=2017-10-18|work=Heddels|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en-US}} Some of the last denim made at White Oak was given to the artist Ian Berry, who is known for his work with denim, to make the 'Secret Garden' at the [[Children's Museum of the Arts|Childrens museum of the arts]] in New York. {{Cite news|url=http://cmany.org/blog/view/look-inside-secret-garden-ian-berry/|title=A look inside The Secret Garden by Ian Berry - Children's Museum of the Arts New York|work=Children's Museum of the Arts New York|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://mymodernmet.com/ian-berry-denim-art-secret-garden/|title=Artist Creates “Secret Garden” with the Last Denim Made in the USA|date=2018-01-15|work=My Modern Met|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.designboom.com/art/denim-ian-berry-secret-garden-01-14-2018/|title=ian berry transforms last spool of denim into a secret garden of whimsy|date=2018-01-14|work=designboom {{!}} architecture & design magazine|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.selvedge.org/blogs/selvedge/the-secret-garden|title=The Secret Garden|work=Selvedge Magazine|access-date=2018-07-09}} == Company comes to an end == The textile companies and plants owned and operated in full or in part by the Cone family were Revolution Cotton Mills, Asheville Cotton Mills, Minneola Manufacturing Company, Salisbury Cotton Mills, Cliffside Mills, Eno Cotton Mills, Granite Finishing Works, Tabardrey Manufacturing Company, Florence Mills, John Wolf Textiles, Olympic Products, and American Spinning Company. The company went private again in 1983 with the threat of a [[corporate takeover|takeover]] by Western Pacific Industries. At the time the company had twenty-one plants and 10,800 employees. The company then had a value of $385 million.Noblitt, p. 3[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30F12F63A5D0C738FDDA80994DB484D81 Cone Mills planning to go private] In 2003, Cone Mills Corporation filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] protection. By 2004, all of Cone's assets had been acquired by W. L. Ross and Company and were then combined with what remained of [[Burlington Industries]] to form [[International Textile Group]].[http://www.voyle.net/Nano%20Textiles/Textiles-2004-001.htm International Textile Group Completes Integration of Burlington and Cone] == The Cone Mill Villages == Mill villages were company-owned towns, built from scratch by textile mills to house their factory workers and their families. In the early 1900s, Cone Mills Inc. built five self-sufficient villages to serve its Greensboro factories. These villages included churches, schools, [[baseball]] fields, community centers, and company stores in addition to houses that were leased to mill workers. At their peak, the Cone mill villages covered {{convert|450|acre|ha}} and housed 2,675 workers in about 1,500 houses. A separate mill village, East White Oak, housed [[African-American]] workers. Thousands of workers and their families made their lives in these “towns within a town” until the company began selling the houses (sometimes to workers) in the late 1940s.Covington, Howard E., Jr. (2008). "Once Upon A City: Greensboro, North Carolina's Second Century," p.43-44. Greensboro Historical Museum,Inc., Greensboro, NC. == References== {{reflist|3}} == Further reading == * Gabriel, Mary, ''The Art of Acquiring: A Portrait of Etta and Claribel Cone'', Bancroft Press 2002, {{ISBN|1-890862-06-1}} * Renouf, Norman, ''Romantic Weekends the Carolinas & the Georgia Coast'', Hunter Publishing 1999, {{ISBN|1-55650-854-9}} * American Council of Learned Societies, ''Dictionary of American Biography'', Scribner publisher 1958, original at [[University of Michigan]] library. *Noblitt, Philip T., ''A Mansion in the Mountains: The Story of Moses and Bertha Cone and their Blowing Rock Manor'', Parkway Publishers 1996, {{ISBN|1-887905-02-2}} * [http://www.lib.unc.edu/mss/inv/c/Cone_Mills_Corporation.html Inventory of the Cone Mills Corporation Records, 1858-1997], in the [[Southern Historical Collection]], [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|UNC-Chapel Hill]] [[Category:Textile companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Greensboro, North Carolina]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1895]] [[Category:Cone family]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies disestablished in 2004]] [[Category:Cotton production]] [[Category:1895 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:2004 disestablishments in North Carolina]]
