Battal Al Mutayri }} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before= [[Mohammed bin Fahd]] | after= Incumbent | title=Governor of East Province | years=2013 – present}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saud bin Nayef}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Saudi Arabia to Spain]] [[Category:Governors of provinces in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Grandsons of Ibn Saud|Nayef, Saud bin]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Portland alumni]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{advert|date=December 2011}} }}
'''Stanley E. Bogdan''' (December 16, 1918 – March 27, 2011) was the founder of S.E. Custom Built, a company dedicated to the handmade construction of fly reels. Bogdan was born in Nashua, NH and lived there throughout his entire life.<ref>Keller, Mitch, ["Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, is Dead at 92"], "New York Times", April 2001</ref> He became interested in fly fishing at an early age when he began receiving outdated copies of a hunting and fishing magazine from a local sports retailer. At age 13, Bogdan was tying his own flies and would then become immersed in the sport.<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref> Upon graduating high school, Bogdan began work at Rollins Engine Company, a local engines manufacturer in Nashua. Later on, while working as a machinist, he began constructing some of the first prototypes for his reels. Stanley Bogdan died on March 27, 2011 and is survived by his son Stephen, and his daughter Cheryl Doughty. His wife Phyllis died in 1995.<ref>Keller, Mitch, ["Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, is Dead at 92"], "New York Times", April 2001</ref> While standing on the shore of one of his favorite rivers; The Grand Cascapedia, Mr Bogdan smiled and said: "I'd die if I could not fish anymore" shortly after Mr. Bogdan could no longer fish he succumbed to pancreatic cancer. 2009
==S.E. Custom Built== S.E. Custom Built fly reels are primarily known for their ability to greatly reduce drag.<ref>Keller, Mitch, ["Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, is Dead at 92"], "New York Times", April 2001</ref> This is mostly attributed to Bogdan's unique concept of the double-break shoe, known as the hallmark of any Bogdan reel. The company is mostly focused on the production of salmon reels, however there have been a few trout reel models made.<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref>
===Company History=== It wasn't until 1955 that Bogdan sold his first set of reels. At the New England Sportsmen's Show, he received $150 from Julian Crandall for a set of 10 reels (one of which Crandall gave to professional baseball player, [[Ted Williams]]). That same year Bogdan would make a deal with [[Abercrombie & Fitch]], one of the day's leading marketers of sport's goods, for a set of 40 reels.<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref> The deal provided that: #Three different models were to be made: 100M, 200M, 300M #An identification code was to be stamped on each reel foot #Anodized gloss black for the reel feet and handles to be used instead of the aluminum serpentine #The reels would sell at $100 retail price granting Bogdan 60% of all sales<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref>
At this time, Bogdan would retire work at the factories and begin working entirely on his reel making company. From 1957 to 1977, S.E. Custom Built would have a relationship with [[Orvis]] including a deal similar to the one with [[Abercrombie & Fitch]]. The [[Orvis]] reels differed slightly because they decided to use Bogdan's original aluminum serpentine colors. Bogdan reels have since been marketed by many of the industry's major tackle merchants.<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref> Eventually demands came for a trout reel in the Bogdan style, so S.E. Custom Built released a 5-weight single-action, non-adjustable, pawl-drag reel in 1976. Demands would come for similar 3-, 4-, and 6-weight reels as well.<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref>
Stephen Bogdan, Stanley's son, would join S.E. Custom Built in September 1973. Stephen purchased the company and became the sole owner in 1996.<ref>Keller, Mitch, ["Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, is Dead at 92"], "New York Times", April 2001</ref>
===Reels=== Two qualities of Bogdan reels that they are most known for are Bogdan's signature double-brake shoe and the 10 position lever provided that is used to regulate drag. They also have black anodized side plates with a pale gold anodized frame.<ref>Marchant, Douglas, [http://westslopefly.com/reels/bogdan.cfm "The Bogdan Story"], "West Slope"</ref> The prices of a Bogdan reel range from $1,500 to $2,400, depending on the type of fish one plans to catch with it. Each Bogdan reel was handcrafted by either Stanley or Stephen.<ref>Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006</ref> These reels are in very high demand and it is not uncommon for one to wait several years to receive their order. Avid reel collector and friend of Bogdan's, Douglas Marchant says, "Since each reel is the product of very intensive hand labor, forecasting delivery is virtually impossible."<ref>Marchant, Douglas, [http://westslopefly.com/reels/bogdan.cfm "The Bogdan Story"], "West Slope"</ref>
Bogdan's reels are owned and praised by some of fly fishing's most notable figures, such as: *John Olin *Lee Wulff *Julian Crandall *Ted Bates *R.L. Haig Brown * Sergey Shakirtov * Paul Lucas
==References== {{reflist}} <!--- After listing your sources please cite them using inline citations and place them after the information they cite. Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. ---> *Keller, Mitch, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/03/sports/03bogdan.html "Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, is Dead at 92"], "New York Times", April 2001 *Hilyard, Graydon R., "Bogdan", Frank Amato Publications Portland, Oregon, 2006 *Marchant, Douglas, [http://westslopefly.com/reels/bogdan.cfm "The Bogdan Story"], "West Slope" *

'''Stockholm City Centre''' (''Stockholms innerstad'', ''Innerstaden'', ''Inre staden'') is the [[city centre]]{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} of [[Stockholm]] in [[Sweden]]. The entire city of Stockholm is also the centre of the [[Metropolitan Stockholm|Stockholm Metropolitan Area]]. Since 2007, Stockholm City Centre is organized into four ''stadsdelsområden'' (sometimes translated to [[Boroughs of Stockholm|boroughs]]): [[Kungsholmen (borough)|Kungsholmen]], [[Södermalm]], [[Norrmalm]] and [[Östermalm]].City of Stockholm: [http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ "Stockholm by districts"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218065732/http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ |date=December 18, 2008 }} Before 2007, Stockholm City Centre was organized into five boroughs: [[Katarina-Sofia borough]], [[Kungsholmen borough]], [[Maria-Gamla stan borough]], [[Norrmalm borough]] and [[Östermalm borough]]. The border between the historical [[Provinces of Sweden|provinces]] of [[Södermanland]] and [[Uppland]] splits Stockholm City Centre in two parts. 179,185 people live on an area of 28.05 km² in the northern (Uppland) part, which gives a density of 6,388.06/km².{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} The same data for the southern (Södermanland) part is 103,646 people on 7.44 km², giving a density of 13,930.91/km².{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} This border is purely historical and has no administrative significance whatsoever. {{wide image|Stockholm stadshuset.jpg|1800px|Stockholm City Centre}} ==Districts== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |+ Sortable table |-bgcolor=#dddddd ! {{more citations needed|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Talitha Getty | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birthname = Talitha Dina Pol | birth_date = {{birth date|1940|10|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Mojokerto]], [[Java]], [[Dutch East Indies]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|7|11|1940|10|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Rome, Italy]] | othername = Talitha Pol | occupation = Actress | spouse = [[John Paul Getty, Jr.]]
(1966–1971) | children = 1 | height = 5'6.5/170cm }} '''Talitha Getty''' (18 October 1940 – 11 July 1971{{cite web|url=http://minimadmodmuses.multiply.com/journal/item/3|title=Talitha Getty: Excerpts from the book "The House of Getty" by Russell Miller|author=Anita Pallenberg|website=minimadmodmuses.multiply.com|date=October 26, 2008|access-date=July 6, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822013402/http://minimadmodmuses.multiply.com/journal/item/3|archive-date=August 22, 2011}}) was an actress and model of Dutch extraction, born in the former [[Dutch East Indies]], who was regarded as a style icon of the late 1960s. She lived much of her adult life in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and, in her final years, was closely associated with the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] city of [[Marrakesh]]. Her husband was the oil heir and subsequent philanthropist [[John Paul Getty Jr.]] ==Early life== '''Talitha Dina Pol''' was born in [[Java]], then part of the Dutch East Indies (now [[Indonesia]]), daughter of the artists {{Interlanguage link multi|Willem Jilts Pol|nl}} (1905–88) and Arnoldine Adriana "Adine" Mees (1908–1948).[https://rkd.nl/explore/artists/92737 Adine Mees] at the [[RKD]] Her father subsequently married Poppet John (1912–97), daughter of the painter [[Augustus John]] (1878–1961), a pivotal figure in the world of [[Bohemian style|Bohemian]] culture and fashion. She was thus the step-granddaughter of both Augustus John and his [[muse]] and second wife, [[Dorelia McNeill|Dorothy "Dorelia" McNeil]] (1881–1969), who was a fashion icon in the early years of the 20th century. By [[Ian Fleming]]'s widowed mother, Evelyn Ste Croix Fleming née Rose, Augustus John had a daughter and Talitha's aunt, [[Amaryllis Fleming]] (1925–1999), who became a noted cellist. Pol spent her early years, during the [[Second World War]], with her mother in a Japanese prison camp. Her father was interned in a separate camp and her parents went their own ways after the war, Pol moving to Britain with her mother, who died in 1948 in [[The Hague]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=/fashion/2008/07/13/st_talithagetty.xml|title=Talitha Getty: Beautiful and Damned|date=2008-07-13|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=2008-08-11 | location=London | first=Justine | last=Picardie}} Pol studied at the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] (RADA) in London. Writer and journalist [[Jonathan Meades]], who was at RADA several years later, recalled that, after first coming to London in 1964, he saw Pol with her stepmother at Seal House, [[Holland Park]] (home of Poppet John's sister, Vivien). Meades thought her "the most beautiful young woman I had ever seen ... I gaped, unable to dissemble my amazement".''Times Magazine'', 11 November 2006 In 1988, a former [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Member of Parliament#United Kingdom|Member of the British Parliament]] [[Woodrow Wyatt|Woodrow, Lord Wyatt]] recalled, with reference to the "success with women" of [[Antony Lambton|Anthony, Lord Lambton]], former [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] Government Minister, that
...there was that Talitha Pol who was very pretty and had a little starlet job in [[Yugoslavia]]; and he went and stayed at the hotel and sent her huge bunches of flowers about every two hours and showered her with presents.Diary, 15 August 1988: ''The Journals of Woodrow Wyatt'', ed Sarah Curtis (1998), p 614
Another to come under Pol's spell was the dancer [[Rudolf Nureyev]], who first met her at a party in 1965. According to Nureyev's biographer, Julie Kavanagh, the two were in thrall to each other, to the extent that Nureyev "had never felt so erotically stirred by a woman" and told several friends that he wished to marry Pol.Julie Kavanagh (2007) ''Rudolf Nureyev: The Life''; ''Sunday Times'', 16 September 2007. Kavanagh surmised that "what [Nureyev] was actually seeing was an exquisite, androgynous reflection of himself". In the event, Nureyev was unable to attend a dinner party given by [[Claus von Bülow]], at which he and Pol were to have been seated next to each other, and so von Bülow invited instead John Paul Getty, son of his employer, the oil tycoon [[Paul Getty]]. Pol and Getty Jr forged a relationship that led to their marriage in 1966. ==Marriage to John Paul Getty== Pol became the second wife of [[John Paul Getty, Jr.]] on 10 December 1966. She was married in a white [[miniskirt]], trimmed with [[mink]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/john-paul-getty-ii-a-very-english-billionaire-673885.html|title=John Paul Getty II: A very English billionaire|last=Hall|first=Malcolm Macalister |date=2001-06-14|publisher=''The Independent''|accessdate=2008-08-12 | location=London}} The Gettys became part of [[Swinging London]]'s fashionable scene, becoming friends with, among others, singers [[Mick Jagger]] of the [[Rolling Stones]] and his girl-friend [[Marianne Faithfull]]. Faithfull has recounted her apprehension, through "ingrained [[agoraphobia]]", about an invitation to spend five weeks with the Gettys in [[Morocco]] ("but for Mick this is an essential part of his life") and how, after splitting from Jagger, she took up with Talitha Getty's lover, Count Jean de Breteuil, a young French aristocrat (1949–1971). Breteuil supplied drugs to musicians such as [[Jim Morrison]] of [[The Doors]], [[Keith Richards]], and [[Marianne Faithfull]], who wrote that Breteuil "saw himself as dealer to the stars"Robert Greenfield, ''Exile on Main St.: A Season in Hell with the Rolling Stones'', DaCapo Press, 2006, pages 55-56Stephen Davis, ''Jim Morrison: Life, Death, Legend'', Gotham, 2005, pages 388-389''Faithfull: an Autobiography'', 1994, page 195 and has claimed that he delivered the drugs that accidentally killed Morrison'True Confessions' (portrait of Marianne Faithfull by Ebet Roberts) in ''Mojo'', September 2014, page 51. less than two weeks before Talitha's own death in 1971. For his part, Richards recalled that John Paul and Talitha Getty "had the best and finest [[opium]]".Keith Richards (2010) ''Life'', page 247 Print designer [[Celia Birtwell]], who married designer [[Ossie Clark]], recalled Talitha Getty as one of a number of "beautiful people" who crossed her threshold in the late 1960s, while couturier [[Yves Saint-Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]] likened the Gettys to the title of a 1922 novel by [[F Scott Fitzgerald]] as "beautiful and damned".''The Times'', November 16, 2006 Among other glamorous figures of the Sixties, the fashion designer [[Michael Rainey]], who founded the Hung on You boutique in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]], and his wife [[Jane Ormsby-Gore]], daughter of British ambassador [[David Ormsby-Gore]] to the United States during the [[John F. Kennedy|Kennedy]] era, "hung out" with the Gettys in Marrakesh between their moving from [[Gozo]] to the [[Welsh Marches]].Obituary of Michael Rainey, ''The Times'', 7 February 2017 John Paul Getty, who has been described as "a swinging playboy who drove fast cars, drank heavily, experimented with drugs and squired raunchy starlets",Compton Miller (1997) ''Who's Really Who!'', p 115 eschewed the family business, Getty Oil, during this period, much to the chagrin of his father. However, in later years, he became a [[philanthropist]] and, as a U.S. citizen, received an honorary British knighthood in 1986. His luxury yacht, built in 1927 and renovated in 1994, was the ''MY Talitha G''. In July 1968, the Gettys had a son, Tara Gabriel Gramophone Galaxy,{{Cite book|last=Miller|first=Russell |title=The House of Getty|publisher=H. Holt|year=1986|pages=262|isbn=0-03-003769-7}} who became a noted ecological conservationist in Africa, dropped his third and fourth forenames, and took [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] citizenship in 1999. He and his wife Jessica (a chalet maid he met in [[Verbier]]) had three children, including a daughter named Talitha.''The Tatler'', May 2011, p 111 ==Marrakesh photo== Talitha Getty is probably best remembered for an iconic photograph taken on a roof-top in Marrakesh, Morocco in January 1969 by [[Patrick Lichfield]].{{cite web |url=http://www.chrisbeetles.com/gallery/picture.php?pic=60742 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417091045/http://www.chrisbeetles.com/gallery/picture.php?pic=60742 |archivedate=2010-04-17 |df= }} See also Lichfield (1981) ''The Most Beautiful Women''] With her hooded husband in the background, this image, part of the collection of the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)|National Portrait Gallery]] in London, portrayed her in a crouching pose, wearing a multi-coloured [[kaftan]], white [[harem (household)|harem]] pants and white and cream boots. The look seemed stylishly to typify the [[hippie]] fashion of the time and became a model over the years for what, more recently, has been referred to variously as "hippie [[chic (style)|chic]]", "[[boho-chic]]" and "Talitha Getty chic".''The Guardian'', July 24, 2005 ==Film career== As an actress, Pol appeared in several films, including ''[[Village of Daughters]]'' (1962) (as a daughter, Gioia Spartaco); an [[Edgar Wallace]] mystery, ''[[We Shall See]]'' (1964) (as Jirina); ''[[The System (1964 film)|The System]]'' (1964) (as Helga); ''[[Return from the Ashes]]'' (1965) (as Claudine, alongside [[Maximilian Schell]], [[Ingrid Thulin]] and [[Samantha Eggar]]); and ''[[Barbarella (film)|Barbarella]]'' (1968), a sexually charged science-fiction fantasy starring [[Jane Fonda]], in which she had the minor uncredited role of a girl smoking a pipe. ==Death== Talitha Getty is rumored to have died of a [[heroin]] overdose in [[Rome]], [[Italy]], on 11 July 1971. However, her death certificate listed the cause as cardiac arrest, with high levels of alcohol and barbiturates found in her blood.(source: source: 1930-, Pearson, John, (1995). [https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/32820398 ''Painfully rich : the outrageous fortune and misfortunes of the heirs of J. Paul Getty''] (1st ed ed.). New York: St. Martin's Press. {{ISBN|0312135793}}[https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/32820398 )]. Ostensibly, she was in Rome to patch up her marriage. She died within the same 12-month period as [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Janis Joplin]], [[Edie Sedgwick]] and, as noted, [[Jim Morrison]], other cultural icons of the 1960s. Her friend [[Brian Jones]] of [[the Rolling Stones]], with whom she had spent time in Marrakesh, had predeceased Hendrix by a little over a year.Getty was slightly older than Morrison and Joplin who were later cited as members of the "[[27 Club]]" of stars who died at that age. Others included [[Brian Jones]] of the Rolling Stones in 1969 and [[Amy Winehouse]] in 2011, when the 27 Club received renewed attention in the media. Sedgwick was 28 when she died. ==Selected filmography== * ''[[Village of Daughters]]'' (1962) * ''[[The Comedy Man]]'' (1964) * ''[[We Shall See|The Edgar Wallace Mystery Theatre]]'' (1 episode, 1964) * ''[[The System (1964 film)|The System]]'' (1964) * ''[[The Long Ships (film) ]] ''(1964) * ''[[Return from the Ashes]]'' (1965) * ''[[Barbarella (film)|Barbarella]]'' (Uncredited, 1968) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0688751|name=Talitha Getty (née Pol)}} * [http://www.blackbookmag.com/article/guccis-cruise-wear-for-earth-mamas/3399 Article featuring Marrakesh photo] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Getty, Talitha}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:1971 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths by heroin overdose]] [[Category:Dutch expatriates in Italy]] [[Category:Dutch film actresses]] [[Category:Dutch television actresses]] [[Category:Drug-related deaths in Italy]] [[Category:Getty family|Talitha]] [[Category:20th-century Dutch actresses]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] [[Category:People from Mojokerto Regency]]

{{advert|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox company |name = UK India Business Council (UKIBC) |logo = Ukindialogo.PNG |type = [[Non-Profit Organization|Non-profit]] |foundation = 1993 as Indo-British Partnership; 2007 as UK India Business Council |location = Millbank Tower, 21-24 Millbank London SW1P 4QP,
[[London]], [[United Kingdom]]{{cite web|url=https://www.ukibc.com/about/contact-us/ |title=Contact Us: UKIBC |publisher= UKIBC|date= |accessdate=14 July 2015}} |key_people = [[Patricia Hewitt]] (Chairman), Richard Heald (CEO) |services = Information Products
Relationship Management
Client Representation
Consulting |homepage = [http://www.ukibc.com/ www.ukibc.com] }} The '''UK India Business Council''' (UKIBC) is a membership-based, [[non-profit organization|non-profit]] organisation founded in 2007 to foster trade and business relations between the [[United Kingdom]] and [[India]].[http://www.ukibc.com UKIBC Website] The organisation works with businesses in both countries, as well as the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and [[India]]n governments, to promote and increase bilateral trade. The UK India Business Council supports UK businesses with the insights, networks, policy advocacy, services, and facilities needed to succeed in India. They help UK companies achieve success whether they are well-established in India or in the early stages of their engagement. Working with the UK Government and other influential and connected partners, they ensure business interests are conveyed to India’s Union and State legislators. The UK India Business Council seek to influence decisions that will make it easier for UK businesses to operate in India. For those seeking practical advice, their team provide a range of sector-specific research, market entry and expansion services that help businesses understand – and take – the opportunities. Their membership network is at the heart of their support. Through a wide variety of events and member-only Sector Policy Groups, they enable businesspeople to meet each other, identify potential partners, suppliers and customers, and to learn from top business leaders and commentators, including those on the Advisory Council. UKIBC is a sister organisation to the [[UK-ASEAN Business Council]] The UK India Business Council is the sole accredited UK Government Overseas Business Network Initiative provider for India. UKIBC is accredited by [[British Chambers of Commerce]] and works in partnership with [[UK Trade & Investment]]. ==History== UKIBC has its origins in the Indo British Partnership (IBP) initiative, signed by then Prime Ministers [[John Major]] and [[P. V. Narasimha Rao]] in 1993.House of Commons, [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmselect/cmtrdind/881/881we30.htm - Trade and Industry - Written Evidence] In 2005 this evolved into a [[Private company limited by shares|private limited company]] called the 'Indo British Partnership Network (IBPN). With the UKIBC receiving increased investment in 2007 from [[UK Trade & Investment]] under direction from then [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|UK Chancellor]] [[Gordon Brown]], [[Sharon Bamford]] was appointed CEO to oversee the transition of the organisation.Free Online Library, [http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Appointment+of+Sharon+Bamford+in+Newly+Created+Position+of+Chief...-a0165963347 "Appointment of Sharon Bamford"] The Rt Hon Patricia Hewitt has been Chair of the UK India Business Council since 2009. [[Lord Karan Bilimoria]], is the founding Chairman of the UK-India Business Council. Lord Mervyn Davies has been appointed as the Chair of UK India Business Council in July 2017. ==Organisation and Leadership== In 2010, Richard Heald, former Vice-President of the [[India]]n arm of [[N M Rothschild & Sons]] was appointed the new CEO of the organisation.Silicon, India, [http://www.siliconindia.com/shownews/Richard_Heald_appointed_new_Chief_Executive_of_UKIBC-nid-70215.html "Appointment of Richard Heald"] UKIBC currently deals with nine major sectors, namely:{{cite web|url=http://ukibc.com/doing-business-in-india/key-sectors/index.aspx |title=Key Sectors Gateway: UKIBC |publisher= UKIBC|date= |accessdate=14 July 2015}} {{Div col}} * Advanced Engineering and Manufacturing * Digital Innovation * Energy * Financial, Legal and Professional Services * Infrastructure * Life Sciences and Healthcare * Retail, Lifestyle and Logistics * Skills and Education * Sports {{div col end}} ==Facilities== ===Business Centers=== UKIBC provides business centershttps://www.ukibc.com/centres/ in [[New Delhi]], [[Gurgaon]], [[Bangalore]] and [[Mumbai]]. ===Market Entry=== UKIBC provides sector-specific research and market entry-related services to help British companies understand the opportunities and make informed choices about their investment ==Strategic partners== The UKIBC is partnered with major following companies{{cite web|url=http://ukibc.com/business-services/ukibc_membership/members_list/ |title=UK India Business Council Members |publisher= UKIBC|date= |accessdate=14 July 2015}} - * [[UK Trade & Investment]] * [[Standard Chartered Bank|Standard Chartered]][http://ukibc.com/ukibc_membership/strategic_partners/index.aspx?name=standardchartered UKIBC Standard Chartered] * [[PwC|PricewaterhouseCoopers]] [http://ukibc.com/ukibc_membership/strategic_partners/index.aspx?name=pwc UKIBC PwC] * [[Barclays]] * [[British Airways]] * [[BT Group|BT]] * [[Cipla]] * [[Dell]] * [[Diageo]] * [[HSBC]] * [[Tata Group|Tata]] * [[AgustaWestland]] ==See also== * [[British business group|British Business Groups]] (BBG) == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.ukibc.com/ Official website of UKIBC] * [http://www.ukibc.com/wmslib/Documents/PDF_Docs/UKIBC_CentreBrochure_July2014.pdf? UKIBC India] ===Others=== * [http://exportbritain.org.uk/latest-news/three-things-you-need-to-know-about-entering-india.html UKIBC introduces a new market entry service 'Launchpad'] * [http://www.sagarsandesh.in/exim-economy/maha-govt-inks-mou-on-ease-of-doing-biz-with-ukibc/ Maharashtra govt inks MoU on ‘ease of doing biz’ with UKIBC] * [http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-11-13/news/44030814_1_uk-india-business-council-csr-indian-market UK set to invest millions in CSR in India] Economic Times, 2013 {{India–United Kingdom relations}} [[Category:Foreign trade of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Business organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Foreign trade of India]] [[Category:India–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:2007 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2007]] [[Category:International nongovernmental organizations]]

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2012}} {{ref improve|date=February 2017}} }} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Aušra Radzevičiūtė | editor_title = Managing editor | frequency = Monthly | circulation = | category = Business magazine
Political magazine | company = Demokratijos plėtros fondas | publisher = | founded = 2007 | country = Lithuania | based = [[Vilnius]] | language = [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] | website = http://www.valstybe.eu/ | issn = 1822-6574 }} '''''Valstybė''''' (lith. for Nation, State) is a [[Lithuania]]n monthly business and political magazine based in [[Vilnius]]. ==History and profile== ''Valstybė'' was launched in 2007.{{cite web|title=Valstybė|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/148848|work=euro topics|accessdate=20 February 2017}} The magazine includes reviews, economical predictions, investment suggestions and interviews. The publisher is VšĮ Demokratijos plėtros fondas. It is based in [[Vilnius]] and is published on a monthly basis. The magazine has a [[Liberalism in Lithuania|liberal]] stance. Since 2010 the magazine names the person of the year.{{cite news|location=Vilnius|title=Lithuanian magazine Valstybe announces Meilutyte person of year 2013|url=http://www.baltic-course.com/eng/baltic_news/?doc=12431|accessdate=20 February 2017|work=The Baltic Course|date=13 January 2014}} It organizes economics conferences.{{cite web|title=The minister attends a forum for economy and policy leaders|url=http://www.am.lt/VI/en/VI/article.php3?article_id=651|work=Ministry of Environment|accessdate=20 February 2017|date=27 February 2015}} In July 2011, the company announce plans to publish the magazine in [[Estonian language|Estonian]] and [[Latvian language|Latvian]]. The same year the editor-in-chief of ''Valstybė'', Darius Varanavičius, was fired following his support for a right-wing extremist party in local elections. In 2010 ''Valstybė'' sold 10,454 copies. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.valstybe.eu/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Valstybe}} [[Category:2007 establishments in Lithuania]] [[Category:Lithuanian magazines]] [[Category:Lithuanian-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2007]] [[Category:Media in Vilnius]] [[Category:Monthly magazines]] [[Category:Political magazines]] [[Category:Business magazines]] {{Europe-poli-mag-stub}}

[[File:Vojtěch Sedláček 2011.jpg|thumb|Vojtěch Sedláček 2012]] '''Vojtěch Sedláček''' (born 1947 in [[Prague]]) is a [[Czechs|Czech]] entrepreneur, who established ''Obsluzna spol.'' (1995) and ''Agentura ProVas'' (1996). Both companies have a mission of creating employment and business opportunities for people with disabilities. In 1973 Vojtech Sedlacek married with Jaroslava Vagnerova (maiden name), they raised four daughters and one son.
==Biography== In 1969, Vojtech Sedlacek began working as a technician and programmer of central computers, at Works of Industry Automatization in Cakovice. Subsequently before the [[Velvet Revolution]] in 1989, he worked in software department at the Research Institute of Mathematical Machines. Since 1981 until 1989 he also volunteered as an instructor of informational technology in the school of Jedlicka for hadicaped children. In 1990 he became the mayor of city of [[Roztoky]] and was elected by the assembly as a representative of the [[Civic Forum]]. In 1991, he was appointed as the head of the office of the [[Czech government]]. From the year 1992 he worked as the executive director and a member of the board of trustees for a printing company CTK Repro. In 1995 he was elected as the board president and executive director of a Citizen Pension Fund. In 1998 he worked as the deputy minister of internal security.
==Professional affiliations and honors==
In 1977, he was among the first people to sign [[Charter 77]].<ref>[http://www.pametnaroda.cz/witness/index/id/2766/page/17?locale=en_GB Memory of nation: Vojtěch Sedláček]</ref> In 2006, he was the national winner of the competition for the social entrepreneur of the year.<ref>[http://www.obsluznaspol.cz/i-EY-Vojtech-Sedlacek.html Social entrepreneur of the year]</ref> In 2007 he was among the first to sign a patition Ligy against antisemitism. In 2008 he became a member of the [http://www.world-entrepreneurship-forum.com World Entrepreneurship Forum] and he participated at its conference in Evian, France. In 2010 he became a member of the World Economic Forum and he participated at its conference in Brussels, Belgium. [[Kepler museum in Prague]] was realised by his Agentura ProVas in 2009. Vojtech Sedlacek is member of Czech Astronomical Society. In 2015 he received [http://www.nadacevia.cz/en/ Via Bona] Award in category The Forging a New Path for innovative support homeless people - project [http://www.nejdrivstrecha.cz/eng.html ROOF FIRST]. Since 2014 is commissioned by Executive Committee of Czech Astronomy Society to lead an Expert Group of Historical Astronomy On the occasion of the 100th anniversary (2018) of its foundation, the Czech Astronomical Society awarded the Honorable Mention for a great merits in the field of astronomy. ==Publications== * Sedláček, Vojtěch, The Astronomical Clock in Prague, {{ISBN|978-80-906961-1-2}} ==External links== * [http://www.agenturaprovas.cz/col/20/home.htm Web Agentura ProVas] * [http://eretz.cz/content/blogsection/12/196/ Liga proti antisemitismu] * [http://www.obsluznaspol.cz/i-EY-Vojtech-Sedlacek.html The Award for Outstanding Social Entrepreneurship] * [http://www.keplerovomuzeum.cz/en/ Web Kepler museum in Prague] * [http://www.world-entrepreneurship-forum.com World Entrepreneurship Forum website] * [http://www.obsluznaspol.cz/i-Sedlacek.html Vojtěch Sedláček - CURRICULUM VITAE, personal website, Czech + English] * [http://www.pametnaroda.cz/witness/index/id/2766/page/17?locale=en_GB Vojtěch Sedláček: Memory of nations] * [http://www.nejdrivstrecha.cz/eng.html Web ROOF FIRST]
{{Authority control}}

'''Waiariki Institute of Technology''' ({{lang-mi|Whare Takiura o Waiariki}}) was a tertiary institution based in the city of [[Rotorua]], [[New Zealand]], in the [[Bay of Plenty]] region in the central North Island. In May 2016, it merged with [[Bay of Plenty Polytechnic]] to form [[Toi Ohomai Institute of Technology]]. Regional campuses existed in [[Taupo]], [[Tokoroa]] and [[Whakatane]], and formerly [[Turangi]] and [[Kawerau]]. These were backed by a variety of specialist campuses and buildings, such as the Waipa Campus just south of Rotorua and the newly established offerings available from Waiariki in the [[Tauranga]] suburb of Windermere. Waiariki was divided into three faculties, which offered masters, graduate, postgraduate and degree qualifications, as well as diplomas and certificates in several subject areas. They were the Faculty of Applied Technology and Primary Industries - Te Kura Takawāo, the Faculty of Business, Information Technology and Creative Arts - Te Kura Taki, and Te Pākaro a Ihenga: Faculty of Health, Education and Humanities. Qualification subject areas included [[nursing]], [[teaching]], [[social work]], [[art]], [[sustainability]], [[Māori culture|Māori]], [[forestry]], [[business]], [[computing]], [[tourism]] and [[hospitality]]. These were backed by an equally diverse range of trade-based qualifications, in areas such as [[engineering]], [[agriculture]], [[horticulture]], [[fashion]], [[carpentry]] and [[hairdressing]]. == Tangatarua Marae == Waiariki has an on-site [[marae]] named Tangatarua, which translates as "two peoples" to reflect their [[bicultural]] nature. Tangatarua Marae was officially opened on 5 October 1996 and is named after a Túhourangi ancestor, Ihenga, who lived on the land where the Mokoia Campus is today. == Academies == The Waiariki Academy of Sport offered talented athletes the opportunity to prioritise their sporting careers while gaining a tertiary education. Similarly, the Waiariki Academy of Singing and Music supported talented young singers and musicians to reach their musical goals while studying. Waiariki also offered teenagers interested in trade areas the Bay of Plenty Trades Academy, which allowed secondary students to get a taste of trade subjects and tertiary life while still at high-school. == History == Waiariki Community College was born in 1976, after the Rotorua Boys’ High School Technical Institute Division was merged with the Rotorua Girls' High School Business College to form a Senior Technical Division under the Rotorua High Schools' Board of Governors. Building on the Mokoia Drive site commenced that year, and the Waiariki Community College was opened two years later on 1 April 1978. Tokoroa's 'outpost' opened in 1973, and subsequently became Waiariki’s first regional campus in 1978. By the time Waiariki Community College changed its name to Waiariki Polytechnic in 1987, it was the largest polytechnic outside of the main city centres. The first two degree-level qualifications in tourism management and nursing were launched in 1995, and three years later, the name finally changed to Waiariki Institute of Technology. ==See also== *[[List of forestry universities and colleges]] ==External links== *[http://www.waiariki.ac.nz Waiariki Institute of Technology website] *[http://www.facebook.com/waiariki.tangata Facebook profile] [[Category:Vocational education in New Zealand]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in New Zealand]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1978]] [[Category:Business incubators of New Zealand]] [[Category:Education in the Bay of Plenty Region]]

{{Infobox person | name = William Dodd | image = The Laboring Classes of England William Dodd.jpg | image_size = | caption = ''The Laboring Classes of England'' | birth_name = | birth_date = 18 June 1804 | birth_place = [[Kendal]], [[Westmorland]], England | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = books about the exploitation of children | children = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] }} '''William Dodd''' (born 18 June 1804) was an Englishman who came to notice when he described his work and growing disability as a [[child labor|child worker]] during the [[Industrial Revolution]]. He was employed by the reformer [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 7th Earl of Shaftesbury|Earl of Shaftesbury]] after writing about child workers in the textile industry, but Shaftesbury later sacked him after accusations were made that Dodd was lying and was a disgruntled employee. He wrote one more book on a related subject that was written and published in America.
==Biography== Dodd was born in 1804 in [[Kendal]], Westmorland and by the age of five he was at work.<ref name=wdodd/> Dodd said that he came from a family that was well remunerated but that had fallen down the class structure by the time he started work.<ref name=labor>Dodd, William (1847) - [[s:The Laboring Classes of England/Letter 1|''The Laboring Classes of England'' - Letter 1: 'Introduction']]'</ref> Dodd came to notice in 1840 when he published with the support of the social reformer [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 7th Earl of Shaftesbury|Lord Ashley]] a book which described his own and his sisters' experiences as child workers. He described how they all worked in a textile factory and sometimes they would work for 18 hours per day.<ref name=albrecht>{{cite book|last1=Albrecht|first1=editor, Gary L.|title=Encyclopedia of disability|date=2006|publisher=Sage Online|location=Thousand Oaks|isbn=9781412950510|url=http://knowledge.sagepub.com/view/disability/n977.xml|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref> Dodd blamed this experience for making him a cripple and by the time he wrote his first book he had had one arm amputated as it had swollen; the doctors later reported that the bone was "honeycomb" and lacked bone marrow.<ref name=wdodd>[http://spartacus-educational.com/IRdodd.htm William Dodd] in ''Spartacus Educational'', retrieved 2 January 2014</ref>
Dodd was able to write the book as he had learnt to write at evening classes<ref name=albrecht/> whilst working in Kendal. It was his job at that time to check the ages of young children who were employed at Isaac and William Wilson's textile mill. His first use of his literacy was to become a clerk at the same mill.<ref name=wdodd/>
In 1837, Dodd briefly started his own school where he passed on his skills in reading, writing and arithmetic. School teaching was meant to suit his increasing disability but he lost the rooms he was renting and this ended the endeavor. Dodd's disability meant that he said that he was unable to find a wife and he resolved to abandon the idea of marriage and he moved to London.<ref name=wdodd/>
In London, he worked as a clerk. After he had his arm amputated, he decided to write his autobiography. The text of ''A Narrative of the Experience and Sufferings of William Dodd a Factory Cripple'' was sent to Lord Ashley, who was well known for his interest in child labour, and it was published. Ashley was a member of parliament and he had campaigned for children to be restricted to a ten-hour day. His motion was defeated but it led to the 1833 [[Factory Acts|Factory Act]] which created a minimum age of nine for working in a textile factory and introduced maximum hours for all children under 12.<ref>[http://spartacus-educational.com/IRashley.htm Lord Ashley], Spartacus, retrieved 2 January 2014</ref> Ashley employed Dodd and he wrote ''The Factory System: Illustrated'' to describe the conditions of working children in textile manufacture, which was published in 1842.<ref>[http://www.historymole.com/cgi-bin/main/results.pl?theme=10001537 Anthony Ashley Cooper], HistoryMole, retrieved 2 January 2014</ref>
These books and Dodd were attacked by Quaker politician [[John Bright]] in a parliamentary committee on the Factories Bill on 15 March 1844. Bright said that he had evidence that the books describing Dodd's mistreatment were in fact created by Dodd's ingratitude as a disgruntled employee. Moreover, he had evidence that Dodd had reported that Lord Ashley was only using him because he was an example of a cripple damaged by work in the textile industry.<ref>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1844/mar/15/hours-of-labour-in-factories#S3V0073P0_18440315_HOC_32 Lours of Labour], House in Committee on the Factories Bill, Hansard, retrieved 3 January 2014</ref> Ashley sacked Dodd who emigrated to America where he wrote ''The Laboring Classes of England'', which was published in Boston in 1847. It is not known where Dodd lived or died after this date.<ref name=wdodd/>
==Works== * ''A Narrative of the Experience and Sufferings of William Dodd a Factory Cripple'' * ''The Factory System: Illustrated'' (1842) * ''[[s:The Laboring Classes of England|The Laboring Classes of England]]: especially those engaged in agriculture and manufactures; in a series of letters'' (1847). (in [[Image:wikisource-logo.svg|16x16px]] [[Wikisource]]).
==Works about Dodd== * "[http://spartacus-educational.com/IRdodd.htm William Dodd]" in ''Spartacus Educational''
==References== {{reflist}}

{{For|other people named William J. Dyer|William Dyer (disambiguation){{!}}William Dyer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2017}} '''William John Dyer''' (1830 – 12 July 1909) was a New Zealand businessman and politician.<ref name="dyer">{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18980331.2.183?query=dyer|title=Biographical Notes of Settlers of the First Decade.|work=[[Otago Witness]]|date=30 March 1898|accessdate=15 January 2017|issue=2300}}</ref><ref name="1859 by-election">{{cite news|url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18590115.2.13|work=[[Otago Witness]] |page=5 |issue=372 |date=15 January 1859|accessdate=19 December 2016 |title=Election of a Member for the House of Representatives}}</ref><ref name="1860-election">{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18601229.2.13|title=Local Intelligence |work=[[Otago Witness]]|date=29 December 1860|accessdate=14 January 2017|issue=474}}</ref> Born in London, his family moved to Sydney when he was a child. He ran a trading business between Sydney, New Zealand and the Pacific Islands, and moved to New Zealand in 1857. He lived at different times in Dunedin and Milton and entered politics, contesting a number of elections and representing the Tokomairaro electorate in the provincial council.
==Personal life==
Dyer was born in London in 1830, but moved to [[Sydney]] in 1839.<ref name="dyer" /> In Sydney, he had two sons, including Frederick James Dyer.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Cyclopedia of New Zealand : Otago & Southland Provincial Districts |year=1905 |url=http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz//tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc04Cycl-t1-body1-d7-d78-d5.html |publisher=[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]] |author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate= 30 January 2017 |location=Christchurch |chapter=Dyer, Frederick James}}</ref> He moved to New Zealand in 1857. His wife, Emma, died in [[Dunedin]] on 18 September 1858 at age 27.<ref>{{cite news |title=Deaths |url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18580925.2.7?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=15 January 2017|work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=356 |date=25 September 1858 |page=5}}</ref> On 21 April 1860, Dyer married Annie Maria Redmayne at the Episcopal Church in Dunedin.<ref>{{cite news |title=Marriage |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18600428.2.10 |accessdate=16 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=439 |date=28 April 1860 |page=5}}</ref> Their first-born son, Ernest Victor, died on 16 February 1861, aged 24 days.<ref name="w. j. dyer">{{cite news |title=Deaths |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18610223.2.12?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=16 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=482 |date=23 February 1861 |page=4}}</ref> They had a daughter on 6 January 1864,<ref>{{cite news |title=Births |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18640108.2.8?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=642 |date=8 January 1864 |page=4}}</ref> a son on 30 September 1865,<ref>{{cite news |title=Births |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18651005.2.10?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=19 January 2017 |work=Bruce Herald |volume=III |issue=78 |date=5 October 1865 |page=5}}</ref> and a further son in 1866.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Cyclopedia of New Zealand : Otago & Southland Provincial Districts |year=1905 |url=http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz//tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc04Cycl-t1-body1-d6-d2-d43.html#t1-body1-d6-d2-d43-d9 |publisher=[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]] |author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate= 30 January 2017 |location=Christchurch |chapter=Blacksmiths, Iron Founders, Etc}}</ref>
==Business career== From Sydney, Dyer traded with New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. When he resided in New Zealand, he was in business in [[Otago]], firstly in Dunedin and later in [[Milton, New Zealand|Milton]] (then known as Tokomairaro). During the [[Otago Gold Rush]], he had a ferry at the [[Taieri River]] at [[Henley, New Zealand|Henley]].<ref name="dyer" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Personal|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT19090713.2.60?query=dyer%20death|accessdate=15 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=14574 |date=13 July 1909 |page=6}}</ref> He lost a number of buildings in a fire in January 1871.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bruce Herald|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18710125.2.13 |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=Bruce Herald |volume=VI |issue=352 |date=25 January 1871 |page=5}}</ref>
==Political career== Dyer was a candidate in the [[Town of Dunedin by-election, 1859|1859 Town of Dunedin by-election]] against [[James Macandrew]] and [[James Gordon Stuart Grant]]. However, he did not participate in the poll that occurred after Grant challenged Macandrew.<ref name="1859 by-election" /> He contested the [[New Zealand general election, 1860–61|1860 election]] in the {{NZ electorate link|Town of Dunedin}} electorate, losing to [[Thomas Dick (politician)|Thomas Dick]] and [[Edward McGlashan]].<ref name="1860-election" /> He was one of four candidates in the {{NZ election link|1871}} in the {{NZ electorate link|Bruce}} electorate and came second, beaten by [[William Archibald Murray]].<ref name="1871-election">{{cite news|title=Election for Bruce |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18710201.2.19 |accessdate=16 January 2017 |work=Bruce Herald |volume=VI |issue=353 |date=1 February 1871 |page=5}}</ref> Dyer also was a candidate in the [[Bruce by-election, April 1865|April 1865 Bruce by-election]], getting defeated by [[Arthur John Burns]].<ref name="1865 by-election">{{cite news |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18650413.2.12|title=Bruce Election |work=Bruce Herald |date=13 April 1865 |accessdate=17 January 2017|volume=II |issue=53|page=}}</ref><ref name="Bruce election">{{Cite news|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18650415.2.31?query=bruce%20dyer|title=Bruce Election|work=[[Otago Witness]]|issue=698|date=15 April 1865|accessdate=3 February 2017|page=11}}</ref><ref name="Bruce election2">{{Cite news|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18650414.2.16?query=the%20election%20for%20bruce|title=Bruce Election|work=[[Otago Daily Times]]|date=14 April 1865|accessdate=3 February 2017|issue=1035|page=6}}</ref> He was also discussed as a candidate in the [[Bruce by-election, July 1865|July 1865 Bruce by-election]], but eventually decided not to stand.<ref name="nomination meeting">{{cite news |title=Tokomairiro |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18650714.2.16?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=19 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=1112 |date=14 July 1865 |page=5}}</ref><ref name="July 1865 by-election">{{cite news |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18650801.2.15 |title=Bruce Election |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |date=1 August 1865 |accessdate=20 January 2017 |issue=1127 |page=5}}</ref>
Dyer was several times [[Mayor of Milton]] and a member of the Otago Provincial Council.<ref name="dyer" /><ref name="Scholefield 1950" /> He stood in the Waihola electorate for the [[Otago Provincial Council]] in May 1863<ref name="Scholefield 1950" /> and was defeated by Alexander Mollison by a single vote.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tokomairaro |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18630616.2.19?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=464 |date=16 June 1863 |page=6}}</ref> When [[John Lillie Gillies]] resigned from the Tokomairaro electorate (i.e. the area around Milton) of the Otago Provincial Council, Dyer contested the election against Thomas Murray and was successful.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Otago Daily Times |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18640830.2.13?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=839 |date=30 August 1864 |page=4}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Tokomairiro election |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18640905.2.24 |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=843 |date=5 September 1864 |page=5}}</ref> He represented the Tokomairaro electorate from 3 September 1864 to 28 July 1866,<ref name="Scholefield 1950">{{cite book | ref = harv |authorlink = Guy Scholefield | last = Scholefield | first= Guy | title = New Zealand Parliamentary Record, 1840–1949 | edition = 3rd | origyear=First published in 1913 | year = 1950 |publisher = Govt. Printer |location = Wellington | page = 224}}</ref> when he resigned.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tokomairiro |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18660818.2.14?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=19 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=768 |date=18 August 1866 |page=9}}</ref>
==Later life== [[File:Queen's Hotel, Oamaru 586.jpg|thumb|Dyer died at his son-in-law's Queen's Hotel in [[Oamaru]]]] Dyer moved to Dunedin in his later life and lived in Cumberland Street (now part of [[New Zealand State Highway 1|State Highway 1]]). On 12 July 1909, he died suddenly during a stay at his son in law's Queen's Hotel in [[Oamaru]].<ref name="OM death">{{cite news |title=Death |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OAM19090713.2.14?query=dyer%20william%20john |accessdate=15 January 2017 |work=[[The Oamaru Mail]] |volume=XXXVI |issue=10198 |date=13 July 1909 |page=2}}</ref> He was buried at Oamaru Cemetery.<ref name="OM death" />
